comments.body: Wouldn't it make sense to check for the minimal supported version before we even start decoding a package?
Good point.

Just to confirm I understand this correctly: In DAML-LF 1.dev every type outside of the type interning table has to be a reference into the type interning table and types inside the type interning table can be arbitrarily complex and contain references into the table at any level.

Yes. 
* `decodeType` enforces (for 1.dev only) that `lfType` is a reference to the the type interning table. (should be use to decode type outside the interning table)
* `uncheckedDecodeType` allows `lfType` to be arbitrarily complex and contain references into the table at any level.  (should be use to decode type inside the interning table)
Thanks for confirming.

comments.body: @remyhaemmerle-da @S11001001 This implementation is probably very bad Scala but I honestly don't know how to do better. The Scala collections library is just confusing me. I'd be interested to improve it under your guidance.

I would just do a fold.

```scala
    lfTypes.foldLeft(Vector.empty[Type]){ (internedTypes, lfType) =>
      val typ = env.copy(internedTypes = internedTypes).decodeType(lfType)
      internedTypes :+ typ
    }
```

Thank you. I assume `Vector` is a mutable data structure with amortized `O(1)` pushing onto the end. Is that correct? If so, could I also take advantage of the fact that I know the final size by reserving that as the initial capacity?
No, `Vector` is immutable with cheap snoc. https://docs.scala-lang.org/overviews/collections/concrete-immutable-collection-classes.html#vectors
Would you still recommend using `Vector` even if I told you that there might be more than 300,000 different entries in the type interning table?
Yes.

I don't really like the idea of using immutable data structures for this at that size and since the mutation is _very_ local, I've decided to use the `ArrayBuffer` solution proposed by @remyhaemmerle-da.

Do we still support decoding DAML-LF 1.5 or older? If we do, wouldn't that mean that we still have to deal with both cases, `actors` present or absent, in the interpreter and this change would not really buy us anything?

DAML-LF 1.5 or latter are deprecated since #5321 that is before the release of SDK 1.0.0. 
We will drop support of  DAML-LF 1.5 or older in the future however for the sake of consistency I prefer not to break reading older version.
ok, I'll have a look at what needs doing here...
This is done now. Thank you.
Why do we not map this to `BEqual` with an implicit parameter?

The type of ``EQUAL_CONTRACT_ID`` contains a universal quantifier (``âˆ€a. ContractId a -> ContractId a -> Bool``). I cannot represent it, using implicit parameters. 
It is the same for `EQUAL_NUMERIC`.

 I do not think it is worthwhile to extend the implicit parameter feature to handle those two cases.
Ah I see, thanks for the explanation! Might be worth capturing in a comment somewhere.
It's also the reason these two had separate representations in the Haskell AST ðŸ™ƒ

comments.body:
We cannot really represent anything bigger than `In32`, so why do we define it as `Int64` in protobuf message?
See: https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/blob/8e144420c4bb23d7bdd01e22aed22f9b7136eb99/daml-lf/data/src/main/scala/com/digitalasset/daml/lf/data/ImmArray.scala#L64
That's specific to the restrictions of the particular collections library this particular implementation happens to be using; nothing to do with the context of the LF language definition.
